statement.tex: If the function \[ \qquad f(x) = \fx \] where $m > 0$ attains its maximum and minimum values at $p$ and $q$ respectively and if $p^2 = q$, then find the value of $m$

reason.tex:
%text $p$ and $q$ are extrema points. Which is why $f'(x) = 0$ at $x = p,q$ And as $p$ is a maxima and $q$ a minima, therefore % \begin{align} \begin{tabular}{NNNc}
\hline \text{At} & f'(x) & f''(x) & Because \\ \hline p & 0 & < 0 & Maxima \\ \hline q & 0 & > 0 & Minima \\ \hline \end{tabular} \end{align} %text Now that we have a strategy in place, we can start to find $m$%

options.tex:
%text
\[ p = m\text{ and } q = 2m \]
\incorrect \[ p = 2m\text{ and } q = m \] %

reason.tex:
%text Every fact in the problem has been given for a reason So, let us use the fact that $p^2 = q$ % \begin{align}
p &= m \text{ and } q = 2m \\ \text{Also }p^2 &= q \implies m^2 = 2m \\ \text{ or } m\cdot(m-2) &= 0\implies m = 0,2 \end{align} %text But $m > 0$ (not $\geq 0$). Therefore, $m=2$ is the only acceptable solution%
